review.title: Multiwinner Approval Rules as Apportionment Methods
review.abstract: We establish a link between multiwinner elections and apportionment problems by showing how approval-based multiwinner election rules can be interpreted as methods of apportionment. We consider several multiwinner rules and observe that they induce apportionment methods that are well-established in the literature on proportional representation. For instance, we show that Proportional Approval Voting induces the D'Hondt method and that Monroe's rule induces the largest reminder method. We also consider properties of apportionment methods and exhibit multiwinner rules that induce apportionment methods satisfying these properties.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: In legislative processes, proportional representation is typically achieved by using methods for distributing party lists, such as the D'Hondt Method or the method with the largest remainder. These methods ensure proportionality by ensuring that each party is assigned a number of representatives in a representative body proportional to the number of votes received. In this paper, we have proposed a simple and natural formal framework that allows us to consider approval-based multi-winner election rules as distribution methods. This framework has allowed us to establish similarities between multiple multi-winner rules, such as the PAV Rule, the Monroe Rule, the Top-k Rule, and the Chamberlin Courant Rule, as well as the appropriate distribution methods. These results provide interesting insights into the nature of the multi-winner rules analyzed, and they show how traditional distribution methods can be extended to environments where voters can vote for individual candidates. We thank Bernard Grofman, Pukkelson and Friedrich Skelson for their helpful discussions.

Principles of justice indicate that, for decisions bodies governed by majority rule, fair apportionment should follow a norm of degressive proportionality [Laslier, 2012, Koriyama et al., 2013]. In fact, degressive proportional apportionments can often be observed in parliaments that gather districts, regions, or states of very different sizes, such as the European Parliament.11 We now provide two examples, both of which are OWA-based.
